I really wanted to like this game. The reviews were great, the trailer looked gorgeous, and the story sounded intriguing. I picked it up when it went on sale for dirt cheap (I'm a broke university student mom with four kids, so I don't get to buy new games very often.).

Unfortunately, the game ended up being exactly what I hate when it comes to actual mechanics. It's an incredibly picky, button-mashing platformer. On top of that, Ori's actions aren't always predictable. Sometimes, when I hit "A," they'd do a simple jump and hit the mark. Sometimes, they'd do a weird little somersault and miss (I didn't have double jump, yet.). At times, they'd slide down a wall instead of sticking, double-jump when I only hit the key once. It was frustrating to no end. It did this with both my keyboard and my controller. 

I played for several hours and it was mostly spent repeating the same spot over and over and over while I tried to hit the key sequence *just right* so that Ori would bounce up a series of walls. I finally deleted the game when I tried one area, no joke, fifty times. It's that difficult. If you like this kind of gameplay, that's great and you'll love this. I do not. I don't have much time to play and wasting it like this when I could be exploring the actual world is not enjoyable at all. 

There were no great discoveries or puzzles to solve during this time. You'd find locked gates, but....surprise! The key is just hidden in a little corner. You literally run into it. No mystery there. I love puzzles and would have liked to have seen more development here.

The artistic style is absolutely adorable and gorgeously crafted. It makes you wish you could actually run through this forest. If Ori was a stuffed animal, they'd be perched on my bed as we speak. Additionally, the enemies are creative and well-matched for Ori's abilities. If this had a little more depth and a little less "hit this spot exactly right," I'd have loved it, even if it made the gameplay itself more difficult.
Brillant, surpass my expectations.

Ori and the Blind Forest hides a fist of steel in an emerald satin glove

The first thing Ori and the Blind Forest hits you with is water colored beauty frosted with golden morning light. I spent at least a minute gazing in wonder at the title screen. Yes, really.

A click on the â€œStart new gameâ€ button later, Ori and the Blind Forest tells the tale of Ori himself in a semi-interactive intro sequence that gives even the first ten minutes of â€œUpâ€ a run for its poignancy money. 

Just a few minutes after that, odds are that the game will kill you for the first time. Because while Ori and the Blind Forest might look like a childrenâ€™s game, when it comes to challenge, it does not screw around.

The likely killer isnâ€™t even one of the cutely corrupted forest animals opposing Oriâ€™s progression, itâ€™s Mother Nature itself with its drowning floods, burning fires, endless chasms and especially its thrice-damned brambles and thorn bushes that pop Ori like heâ€™s a balloon. You will die when a jump is too short. You will die when a jump is too high. You will die when after a harrowing sequence of flawlessly executed actions the very last button hit came a bit too late or too early. These are the deaths that result in teeth marks left in the controller. 

And yet, despite the high level of death-related frustration, I never felt any inclination to walk away from this 2D metroidvania. Partly because the titular Blind Forest is so jaw-droppingly gorgeous, with its greens and purples and violets, with its moody shadows and glorious sunlight, with all those lovingly crafted little animations and artistic touches. Partly because I was invested in helping Ori through his hero arc. But mostly because playing was so much fun mostly because one primary feeling the game inspires: momentum. 

When Ori isnâ€™t busy bleeding out on another bloody thorn, the slightest button prompt makes him glide through the level like a leaf on an especially cineastic breeze.  Double jump, dash and glide allow for movement chains that donâ€™t touch the ground for 10 seconds or more. Playing Ori is simply delightful. 

Not every moment I spent with the game was quite as wonderful. There are a few brutal difficulty spikes that surpassed even the already high base level of PC mortality. The lack of enemy variety hurts the game a bit, as does the strange checkpoint system that allows the player himself to determine where he would like a checkpoint to be. The problem is that you pay for the position of a checkpoint with a resource you might run out of, which allows the player to completely screw himself, especially since Oriâ€™s stronger attacks consume the same resource. Next time, please take that particular freedom away from me again. 

As I got better at the game and Ori got his paws on quite a few life bar extensions, the engagement curve smoothed out and the rage-inducing instakills became quite rare. Ori is the rare game where the last third is actually the most fun. The story wraps itself up in a bittersweet  finale with a hopeful denouement, and then you are free to fly through the entire map like lightning, hovering up the last collectibles to your heartâ€™s content and finally, leave the game and immediately install its sequel. Ori and the Blind Forest might be a harsh mistress, but she has a lot of joy to give, as well.

TLDR: A charismatic metroidvania with beautiful art, a world class movement system and a charmingly simple and evocative story. Just be aware that it will kill you. A lot.

I don't normally write reviews on games often, and that's mainly due to me liking to keep my opinions to myself, but y'all. Let me tell you a little something.

Metroidvanias are in a weird spot for me. I will either play the game for hours on end due to how addicted I am to it (Hollow Knight is a very good example of this), or I will not be interested in it at all. The Ori franchise has always been on my radar due to my general liking of fantastical scenery and mystical things, but never really put the time nor money aside to give it a proper shot. I've heard from close friends how good the game was, but it was only just recently I finally pulled the trigger on the series (since it has a bundle deal to get both The Blind Forest and Will of the Wisps for a really good price).

Y,all. I'VE BEEN MISSING OUT THIS WHOLE TIME.

If a game has me fantasizing the experience and setting of the game AFTER I have finished playing it (whether it be to take a break or after completing the story), that says something, and Moon Studios absolutely nailed it with this game. A fluid movement system for Ori (the character you play as), a cohesive combat system that allows you to pair some abilities together at the same time, and a map that consistently challenges you to use your wits and be alert to your surroundings, while also being intertwined in a way that's satisfying.

To be honest with you, I would love to see more attention to detail on the lore aspect of this universe, such as where did Kuro come from, or how the Spirit tree was formed (honestly, if this was already stated within the game, then I'm just being a dense mfer per usual).

And the music? ABSOLUTELY BLISSFUL. I don't think I've had any other game hit me with any sort of emotions unlike this. With suspenseful transitions and pure ambience for each location, the music seriously hit every single note right (get it...?), and the people behind the sound design and coordinating the OSTs know exactly what they're doing (and it's honestly a big inspiration for me to understand composition as a whole).

To end this, how can I rate this game?

9.5/10

Everything this game has to offer is nearly perfect and works amazingly with each other, and I think any player, new or experienced in Metroidvanias, can have an awesome time with this game. However, if more can be done to expand the lore/universe, this will easily be a 10/10 (albeit this game is already one of my personal favorites as of recent years).

The story line leaves much to be desired. The game play is good, except that the air seems to be very thick, such that it's like Ori is moving through jelly the entire time. All that said, I do still want to get the sequel, so it's good enough for that :)

Setting aside the controversial articles surrounding the work atmosphere at Moon Studios, I'm going to solely focus on the game: you know how many people feel when they wake up on Christmas morning (or another equivalent holiday)? It's warm in the house, you have your favourite sweater on, and your fluffy childhood socks that maybe your grandma knitted or you bought from a winter bazaar, and it's snowing outside, you stretch in your bed, go to the kitchen and make yourself a cup of steamy hot cocoa or hot chocolate, and take a sip. And you just sit there inhaling everything around you. You smile. Life is simple. You're happy. This is what Ori and the Blind Forest feels like. The music is how I imagine the word tranquility would sound. If you've ever played WoW, the druid class has a spell called Tranquility, can't describe it better. The artwork is spectacular, I love it! There are some maddening sections in the game, I must admit that but after a couple (of dozen) attempts you get the hang of it. 

All in all, I enjoyed the time I spent going on an adventure with Ori in the Blind Forest. 10/10 would recommend if you're a fan of the genre. Happy exploring, folks!

Ori and the blind forest is a metroidvania with a touching story
I replayed this game about 8 times now and i bought it twice (originally had it on console)

So i could easily recommend this game its my top 1 favourite game
But lets dive deeper in
Positives
- Good story
This game has one of the stories that would make you actually feel emotional
- Fun gameplay
The abilities all have a purpose and can be used in combat and the likes
- Good map design
The world is made very well with details everywhere for the first time the game may be slightly confusing but afterwards it is very easy to find your way around. (this is kind of a given for metroidvania's though)
- Amazing graphics
The graphics of this game are still breath taking even though its old it won't be 4K raytraced quality but it looks amazing nonetheless

Negatives
- Punishing gameplay
Certain parts of the game are extremely punishing and unfair
if you're playing on hardcore this isn't a issue however if you are it's a huge issue
- 100% map exploration is tedious
While 100%'ing a game is never a easy task with ori there are scenarios where you will sometimes miss a slight spot and its impossible to see this on the map as such you have to walk circles to find it
This can be annoying as you will be running the same area 12 times before finding that one spot you needed to find
- Easy combat
You don't have any crazy weapon's and the likes as such you will often be sitting there pressing a button until the enemy dies. This isn't bad but if your a person that likes intense combat you may have to make it more intense yourself by doing funny tricks

Ori drew me in with its beautiful narration at the start of its game, beautiful art style, and friends recommending me to play it. It has a lovely story with cinematic presentation, but the gameplay / presentation is a bit disappointing in comparison:

Throughout the game, you ALWAYS run away from something. Run out of temples after restoring them, run away from natural disasters, run away from the angry bird - in theory, this wouldn't be a problem. However, the realization after the third escape sequence made me realize that the game felt way too repetitive. I wished escaping could at least feel different, but it didn't. It always felt the same, over and over again.

I thought the skill tree was interesting. It having requirements helped balance out from capping out one aspect disproportionately seemed alright. Though the combat itself was pretty sad. For most of the game, you're fighting the same enemies rehashed with a slightly more powerful projectiles and more health to tank more hits. It also gets stale.

You can raise your maximum HP, but then the enemies and the environment proportionately harm you more than before. This would be fine, but in practice makes it so you never can tank more hits or mistakes from anything. It just feels like you're not making any progress as a player. 

All of this together makes for an experience that feels very frozen in time. It never feels like you make progress, it always feels like you're doing the same thing, and not even the combat changes. Also, at times puzzles seemed to make me get stuck for obnoxiously long periods of time. Then, when I look it up, it turns out that majority of other players were stuck in the exact same place makes it feel less my fault and more the game failing to properly indicate me what to do.

Ori and the Blind Forest, for me personally, is the bane of my existence. I cannot hide how much frustration and hatred this game made me feel. Objectively, it's an alright game. Just painfully boring gameplay-wise... puzzles can be alright. But randomly stumbling into the ending without realizing that was the finale of the game was really.. disappointing. Love the art style, characters, and story. The gameplay just made me feel really apathetic about the whole thing. Wouldn't recommend the game unless you're really invested in the story and world building.

Ori and the Blind Forest, is a cute and heartwarming platformer that I would recommend to not only fans of the genre but to anyone willing to give such a game a shot. 

The art direction and music are truly stunning, cute and generally breathtaking.The story is heartwarming, a tribute to parental love and found family. As far as gameplay goes (and this comes from someone that really dislikes platformer type games) it is pretty solid. The puzzles are fun and not super hard, the platforming and moving around is generally enjoyable, especially the "boos fight" escapes. There are some parts that got me frustrated, but then again, not a huge fan of platfoermers. 

Overall, I'd give Ori and the Blind Forest a solid 9/10 and I will definitely be revisiting again at some point in the future.

I bought this game a few years ago based on it's glowing reviews and forgot about it for a great long while. What a shame! I'm go glad I decided to start this game up but what hasn't been said about this game that I can possibly input? A bit disappointing. Do not misunderstand, [i]Ori[/i] is not a [i]bad[/i] game at all. It is quite beautiful in both art style, actual visuals, soundtrackâ€¦ it all comes together nicely. What disappoints is how utterly banal it all ends up being. A story that tries very hard to be the indie 101 with a child character lost in a scary world alongside a somber soundtrack, but unlike, say, [i]Ender Lilies[/i], I cannot say I ever cared for this one. Not only does the narrative destroy all sense of gravitas it had towards the end and turned excessively formulaic, I found the gameplay stood in the way of the narrative entirely too much.
Gameplay is an interesting one here. After dealing with the Ginso Tree I felt the game came into its own, as most movement options (notably the very cool bash) are now available and controls stopped feeling awkward, turning traversal from chore to joy. A curious development that I felt again on successive playthroughs and thus also highlights Oriâ€™s own growth. If I see [i]Ori[/i] more as a platformer than a metroidvania, my view certainly becomes more favorable, however, the platforming never came into its own for me. It seems as if all the game knows are spikes and instant kill lasers. The spikes in particular feel egregious in some places where due to yet underdeveloped movement options, the game asks you to make precise jumps up cliffs with the spikes jutting out just a few more pixels than it seems, which combined with the rather floaty controls never stopped feeling like cheap hits. Those felt particularly awful when I went for the one life difficulty. And then you get all these cool movement options and the game does what with it? Tunnels of spikes and/or lasers. Glide through the tunnel of spikes. Glide through the tunnel but stop just before the laser gets you and pass it quickly when it pauses. It got old quickly, whereas some of the parts that I found more interesting, like bashing rocks through wind passages to make barriers were comparatively rare. Not like those were grand revelations in game design, but it felt much better than maneuvering around yet more spikes. And then there are the escape sequences, which are technically amazing â€“ the tense music, how you are in a rush andâ€¦ oh, you did not know the path because this is your first time? Too bad, now have fun dying every step along the way because you did not know that the ceiling crushes you if go too far. No, you cannot outspeed the water, it rubberbands right back to you, now enjoy having missed the timing by a few frames and starting over yet again, music and all. It is not hard, but tedious. Gameplay and narrative were so massively at odds with each other here that I just grew apathetic to these supposedly (in)tense situations. I guess there is also the combat. Um. It is supremely bad and the game would have been better off without it, which would have aided it in the visual clarity department as well, as I found the variety of glowing blobs (including yourself) to be beyond annoying to read well.
For the most part, I did enjoy the game nonetheless, particularly how you can break some sequences or just be creative with throwing light balls to make your own bashing points. And while that felt amazing, I was overall not too impressed with [i]Ori[/i]. It might just be that while I have finally gotten around to playing it, it is just too late now, almost ten years later. Particularly so after I have played both [i]Hollow Knight[/i] and [i]Celeste[/i], which might be a bit of an unfair comparison but to me they highlight the weaknesses of both the metroidvania and platforming elements so much more.

I would call myself a seasoned veteran of platformers, specifically, I've played Mario kaizo and modded celeste. A wonderful little game with charming graphics, tight controls and a simple but effective story. i should warn anyone who is playing though that while the aesthetic of Ori looks cozy and adorable, the game is far from a "chill" experience. It requires fast reflexes and precise platforming. That being said, it is a gem in what it seeks to achieve.

While the art style of Ori is the star of the show, the level design and ability mechanics keep things interesting as well. The metroidvania aspect of the game also means that those who like being completionists can get even more playtime out of the game by going back to old regions and discovering secret locations or areas that were earlier locked. I also enjoyed the fact that there is no real spoken language in the game, and even if you don't read the little text that they do show on-screen, the story is strongly portrayed just through visuals.

The only parts that frustrated me a little were the "escape" sequences where you are expected get through an entire section at once without making any mistakes. These portions tend to be more 'trial and error' than puzzle or skill based, but they are few and far between, so it is forgivable.

Still a great metroidvania, with exceptional art and exploration. And a simple but captivating story. 

My only criticism would be that it isn't always obvious that you are ready to explore and finish a new section of the map. And in the endgame it's a bit too easy, with all skills unlocked.
Tough as nails but with a heart of gold, Ori and the Blind Forest will definitely test your platforming and puzzle solving skills while taking you on an hell of a beautiful journey.
No

I love how the movement in this game feels- Ori is lightweight and fluid, dashing in and out and over obstacles with ease. The game doesn't feel unfairly hard- if I make a mistake and die, I can easily understand why it happened and how i should start fixing the issue. The story is emotional despite not having any dialogue, and though it's perhaps not the most unique, it's still full of potential as a heartwarmer and tearjerker both.

The "boss" battles of the game are intense chase sequences which test your mastery of new abilities, and they're full of a healthy adrenaline. Unfortunately, some parts can have /very/ steep reaction time requirements, and it can sometimes feel like you're intended to die as a learning experience and start over, instead of escaping by the skin of your teeth. This interruption of flow can be very jarring!

The music and the art, are, of course, top notch, and I don't think there's a single moment in the game that looks or sounds bad.

Not a recommended despite the game's quality in animation and overall artistic direction. I heard the story was majestic but I just found it good, not more.
What frustrated me the most were the controls and after playing games like Hollow Knight, it feels very frustrating coming back to Ori and having to push 4 different buttons to do the equivalent of the crystal dash. 
Also, the game seems unfair at times, putting some segments closer to die n retry than actual skilled platforming, making it very frustrating.
Finally, the difficulty is a bit problematic. My fault in a way, as I always play my games on Hard or Very Hard for a challenge. Here, I oscillated between pure skill and unfairness, frustrating me even further when i realized that some end game enemies were one shotting me, although I had all optional Life Cells. 

So... here we are. This is not recommended but I didn't hate it. It's a shame to see such majestic artistic direction in an often frustrating game. Didn't play Ori 2 but I hope It's better because there's a great potential.

[h3]Exploration: 4/5[/h3]
Ori and the Blind Forest offers a beautiful interconnected world filled with hidden areas, secret abilities, and lore that rewards exploration. The game's map contains various regions that are visually distinct and offer unique challenges. Backtracking is encouraged as new abilities allow access to previously unreachable spots in previous areas. However, the game is more linear compared to other Metroidvania titles, with a clearer progression path that somewhat limits the experience of exploration.

[h3]Gameplay: 4/5[/h3]
The gameplay in Ori and the Blind Forest is fluid and responsive, with a focus on precision platforming. While Ori doesn't jump high, he can move fast and jump far, and the game introduces a variety of abilities that make traversal increasingly dynamic and engaging. The platforming challenges are well-designed, requiring both timing and skill. While combat is present, it takes a backseat to exploration and platforming. The Definitive Edition also introduces new abilities and areas, further enhancing the gameplay experience.

[h3]Progression: 4/5[/h3]
Progression in Ori and the Blind Forest is satisfying, with a well-paced introduction of new abilities that enhance both combat and exploration. As you progress, youâ€™ll find life and energy cells that increase your health and energy reserves, as well as ability points for use in the skill tree. The Definitive Edition also adds new areas that provide additional upgrades and abilities, enriching the overall progression. Unfortunately the game tells you where to go, so the progression can be quite linear unless you deliberately go back to previous areas.

[h3]Narrative: 4.5/5[/h3]
Ori and the Blind Forest delivers an emotionally charged story rather than using environmental storytelling. The story is simple yet powerful, centered around themes of love, loss, and sacrifice. The gameâ€™s narrative is driven by its beautifully animated cutscenes, but it still has some dialogue. The connection between the player and the characters is strong, and the story unfolds in a way that is both heartfelt and impactful. The Definitive Edition also adds new narrative elements that further deepen the story and world.

[h3]Visuals: 5/5[/h3]
Visually, Ori and the Blind Forest is stunning, with beautiful artwork that brings the world to life in a breathtaking way. The gameâ€™s vibrant color palette and detailed environments create a magical atmosphere that is both immersive and captivating. Each area of the game is distinct, with its own unique aesthetic that enhances the overall experience. The animation is fluid, and the attention to detail in the character designs and backgrounds is exceptional. The Definitive Edition maintains this high standard, making Ori one of the most visually impressive platformers ever made.

[h3]Music: 4.5/5[/h3]
The soundtrack of Ori and the Blind Forest is spectacular, with a score that perfectly complements the gameâ€™s emotional and atmospheric tone. Composed by Gareth Coker, the music enhances the emotional impact of the story and the grandeur of the world. The orchestral score is both powerful and evocative.

[h3]Difficulty: 3.5/5[/h3]
Ori and the Blind Forest has some challenging gameplay, particularly in the platforming sections. The game requires precise timing and skill, which can be difficult, especially during the escape sequences. However, the game is punishing, with progress lost upon death and very little autosaving (requiring soul links which need energy to place).

[h3]Replayability and Content: 3/5[/h3]
Completionists may find satisfaction in uncovering all the secrets and achieving 100% completion. However, once the game is fully explored and you've gotten all the achievements, there isn't much reason to play it more.

This game is aggressively mediocre.  A solid 5/10.
The graphics are really pretty, and the music is good for sleeping to.
The controls feels sloppy and the combat may as well be non-existent.
There are a lot of surprise kaizo style traps that will pull you out of the immersion of the story.  And it's never really clear what is part of the playing field and what is part of the super graphical background.  There were quite a few times I was just running along and would die and be like 'Wait, what hit me.  Ooh that's not background.'
The bright colorful scenery and background make it incredibly hard to tell what are the attacks you should be dodging.  Likewise, the foreground scenery often gets in the way of seeing what you're doing.
The game is very inconsistent about hazards.  For instance, first purple water is damaging, then blue water is deadly, then blue water is fine, then green water is deadly, then one time during an escape sequence you have to jump into green water immediately to avoid death, and it's safe.
Ori controls like they're constantly drunk. Attacks are inconsistent in both trajectories and damage.
Every hidden 'secret' in the game is just something hidden behind foreground scenery or something that requires you to find a hidden switch to stomp or torch to light.
Every 'dungeon' ends with a metroid style 'escape' that you can't save during.
Saves are on you, you have to spend energy to save, but you can do it anywhere, but it's like save states.  Early game I almost never did it because I would forget.  But after having to collect the same collectables or watch the same cutscenes multiple times, I got to the point of just saving every time I walked into the next room.
The harder aspects of the game, it expects you to just know or figure out, which is fine.  But the easier aspects of the game, it will not stop giving you tooltips for.  I was in the last dungeon getting 'Hold RT to grab and move rocks' hint pop-ups.
The sound balancing is awful.  Like trying to watch a cinema release movie on a home TV.  You turn it up enough to hear basic sound effects and then a bird will screech and deafen you for the next half hour.
But the worst of all of it is the story.  The story is absolutely terrible.
It seems to be all about the extents parents will go for their children, but not one decision made by any of the 'parents' in the game is remotely close to a good one.  I'll avoid spoilers here, but it's a constant cycle of guilt-tripping, narcissistic behaviors, lack-of-forethought, and just the most terrible decision making I have ever seen in a game's story.  They even managed to include a bit of racism too.

Despite all of these things, the game was pretty, and it was alright to play.  I did 100% it, mostly to make sure I didn't miss any potential terrible bits of story to make fun of.
I didn't hate playing it, but I would say the difficulty curve was probably higher than most people who tend to enjoy indie arthouse style games would like.
But for being a 'puzzle' platformer, there never was a puzzle that I solved and felt good about.  It was always just a matter of me scouring the area until I found the switch or lantern or lever I had missed and then rolling my eyes.
There were a few good ideas in the game.  Like I really love the bash ability and being able to jump off of projectiles and monsters and stuff.
But overall, it just felt like someone made a game out of what should have been a movie.

I wish I could recommend this game because I liked it. it has beautiful graphics and a good soundtrack, and the somewhat shallow story is enjoyable, but that's where my praises end. The gameplay and mechanics in this game suck and are very poorly explained. the majority of the game is platforming but the mechanics for the movement are imprecise at best and straight-up shit at worst or half the time you just don't know what to do because the game didn't tell you. the main way to move vertically is to dash off of certain objects, the problem is a good majority of the objects you need to dash off are enemy attacks. There is a dungeon right near the end of the game where the only way to move up is to dash off enemy attacks but the problem is half of the time they wouldn't attack so you're stuck just floating down into fire or spikes praying to get what you need. The save system is also abhorrent the only time you get an auto-save is either in dungeons or after a "boss", the only way to make a manual save is to use your "mana" but you also need your mana to do your stronger attacks so you often don't have much left. But even when you do have your mana it just doesn't let you save half the time because you're either too close to an enemy or in some sort of "chase sequence". I put the chase sequence in quotations because it's less of a chase and more of a sprint in the dark, right at the start of a chase you get an auto-save and then you must make precise jumps using the imprecise mechanics or you half to restart. Most of my time in the final chase was spent either waiting for the camera to catch up with me or dying because I was just slightly too slow and missed a cycle, thus being forced back to the start. now I know I have like 18 hours in this game but most of that was spent paused just contemplating my life choices after dying in the same BS 40 times. this could be a good game but it is held back drastically by garbage mechanics. Despite all this I still intend on playing the sequel, I hope it is better.

TLDR: A Masterpiece--Visually stunning, beautiful music, emotional story, and thrilling platforming/movement.  

This is without a doubt the most gorgeous game I've played, with every frame (including gameplay) looking like it could have been ripped from a high-budget feature film.  The lighting, detail, framing, animation, and art style are all incredible.  

The game features a beautiful and dynamic fully orchestral soundtrack that is a perfect fit for the art and gameplay and is even an essential part of the game's style of storytelling.  

As advertised, although simple, the story is an emotional experience about love. I especially appreciate how much of it is told visually and musically, allowing many of the scenes to speak for themselves without dialogue.  

This game's movement (and thus the platforming) is one of my favorites in any game.  The action (after gaining a few abilities) is extremely fluid and engaging, with skill and an understanding of the mechanics rewarding the player with grace and speed in a very satisfying way.  Even simple traversal of the world is fun.  The "Bash" ability specifically is a real standout and one of the greatest abilities and mechanics in any game I've played, offering movement, positioning, offensive, defensive, and puzzle-solving capabilities all in one sleek package that pairs excellently with the other abilities.  

My only complaint (and it's minor) is that completing "One Life" mode shouldn't be an official achievement or the mode should have instead been a "One HP" mode.  It's a bit too punishing with how many insta-kills there are and encourages a slower, more conservative play-style that conflicts with the identity and flow of the game.  Practice each section several times on another save file if you intend to complete it.

[h1] A game where a KKK-styled light "spirit" Tree eradicates all darkborn creatures for free, and owns all lives on Nibel, like a mad god...[/h1]

Spicy heading aside, i can't believe the main story revolves around mindless extermination of all life that isn't light-born. It's all about the classic survival of the fittest, in a world where [strike]white[/strike] light-suprematists have to win.

Because of this, a darkborn Owl mom gets mad because all her helpless chicks got burned away by a wave of light, seeks revenge, and obtains death in return, because light must be restored in the world (and all darkborn creatures have to suffer and die).

[h3] A gameplay that keeps telling "it will get good in a few hours" [/h3]
I won't sweeten the pill. Ori and the blind forest is HARD.
Combat is not that hard, just boring and cheesy, but the platforming requires very precise inputs in order to pass.

At start, when you're helpless and frail, everything can kill you by sneezing in your general direction.
Thorny bushes? (lots and lots of) death.
Spiders? Death
Slimes? death

What helps lighten the burden is [b]the ability so save pretty much everywhere you like[/b], given you have energy to spend. This allows some heavy trial-and-error mindset to kick in until you pass.

Some sections - three - requires you execute to near-perfection the forced-scrolling scene in order to survive and, believe me, the game is quite ruthless.

[h3] An overall beautiful scenery [/h3]
The world of Nibel is very colorful and makes you think its thriving with life -  ruthless life. Pretty much every location is great looking and cruel at the same time. Swimming in the few aquatic sections is a dream.
This game is fantasticâ€”if you're into platformers, of course.  As for me, they lead to screaming, cursing, and a deep desire of punching something.

[h1] Thrilling, Aestethic, Unique [/h1] 
Ori and the Blind Forest hit me as an overall great experience. It effectively combines the Metroidvania style of gameplay with a solid narration and incredible art style, creating a true gaming gem.
[h2] What I liked [/h2] 
The visuals are just stunning, with great usage of colors and 2D animation.
The music is very fitting and helps build the emotional charge of the game.
The story is simple, yet extremely effective: it will make you cry and smile within a few hours of play.
The gameplay is fun and well crafted, with the highest difficulty being a nice challenge for experienced players.
[h2] The only thing I didn't like [/h2]
In short, the escape sequences. While they are very cinematic and engaging, the magic stops as soon as you die a couple of times, and realize there will be no checkpoints until you complete them, leaving you in a trial and error situation. Definitely not a deal breaker but still, they don't live up to the quality of this great work of art.

This game can be definitely used as an example to prove that video games are, indeed, art.

[b] Recommended for players of all ages and tastes. [/b]

I feel like Iâ€™m going insane seeing how well reviewed and acclaimed this game is. It manages to be short, tedious, oversaturated, and shallow all at once. Finished the story waiting to get to the good part just to see the credits roll after the least interesting final sequence of all time.

The combat mechanics are horrifying. I know itâ€™s not the focus, but if thatâ€™s the case make it quick. The damage you deal with the stupid auto aim button mash attack is near useless, the oone that uses the same resource as SAVING THE GAME is slow and clunky, and the only thing that actually does any damage, bash, requires you to wait for a projectile and throw yourself in the opposite direction two or three times. Itâ€™s fine to make the game about platforming, but if thatâ€™s the case then stop putting random useless barriers in front of the platforming. The most insulting bit was reusing the same boring, time consuming â€œpop up out of the groundâ€ boss thing on several occasions. Just play the unskippable cutscene and get it over with.

And despite the fact that puzzles and platforming are the only mechanics that the developers gave more than a minute of thought to, theyâ€™re barely better than the combat! The only times I actually thought about an interesting way to solve a puzzle were when I missed the â€œinstantly solves this puzzleâ€ button in the next room, or needed an ability I didnâ€™t have yet. The depth goes no further than â€œhere is a new mechanic. Use that mechanic in the most obvious possible way, also thereâ€™s like seven random spots to use this specific ability scattered around the map.â€ 

Platforming and moving around were just okay. Early game is frustrating because you have no ways to move around, and by the time that you have them the imprecision of the controls and floor layouts are very apparent by the way that they instant kill you over and over. Several memorable times where I needed to stand on a wobbling platform, or walked too close to a corner where the floor turns to spikes, or needed to wait for an enemy to decide to shoot at me while I floated towards the lava with no meaningful way to interact with it. Any time I forgot to save immediately after making marginal progress on a puzzle or after watching a cutscene/getting a game pause for a mandatory explanation was time wasted on the next random thing that killed me.

The gameâ€™s issues are at their most glaring during the escape sequences. Because they decided to put no checkpoints in them, and speed up the environmental hazard if you get too fast, none of the individual portions can be all that challenging or interesting. But, inevitably, there will be something in the back half that you fuck up a few times or arenâ€™t sure what the game is asking you to do and you get to restart the entire thing. The last fire section, the most â€œcinematicâ€ and climax of the game, kept having the camera lag behind to look at the owl while I did the early sections half off-screen, then killed me when I clipped a corner of the geometry somewhere. I get that youâ€™re proud of how pretty the game is, but let me play it please.

The gameâ€™s art and music are alsoâ€¦ just okay? It certainly feels high budget, but the character designs, especially Gumo and the gorilla thing, are off putting and not very well animated. The world is so focused on having texture and bright lights and beauty that itâ€™s often hard to tell apart the background and the foreground - and a major reason the combat feels terrible is you canâ€™t see a damn thing with all the particle effects on the dinky autoaim attack. My absolute biggest gripe is how often the game uses that same title screen music chord progression - seriously every emotional beat uses the same music, it loses all its impact immediately and is SUCH a strange decision for a game with as high of a budget as this seems to have had. Write a second song.

The only other thing the game has that itâ€™s praised for is the story, which was basically nonexistent. The two gods in the story just sort of accidentally kill each otherâ€™s kids, get mad, and then stop just short of doing it again because the owl learned to be kind after accidentally almost killing its own kid and you. Iâ€™m being reductive, but itâ€™s really not any deeper than â€œkindness winsâ€.

Maybe graciously, the game is also amazingly short. My save file, with about an hour or so of idle time, came to only 6 and a half hours to beat the main game. Obviously, I didnâ€™t do everything, but anyone decent to mediocre at platforming and not hellbent on 100%ing isnâ€™t likely to get more than 4 or 5 hours out of this. Even on sale, thatâ€™s a tough buy compared to the countless games that do every element of this game better and with more interesting, varied, lengthy content to go with it. What a waste of time.

A short, metroidvania type platformer.

Pros:
-Beautiful artstyle and character designs
-Heartfelt story
-Great soundtrack
-Interesting abilities

Cons:
-Some of the game design is questionable. Unintuitive or even counterintuitive in some cases (in one case you are expected to use a power to break something which should not otherwise break from using that power...).
-There is an extremely steep learning curve early on. Several times you will learn a new skill and then be immediately forced to become an expert at it.
-Some of the time sequenced events are absolutely terrible. And the game will autosave over your save file at the start of the sequence, so you can't just come back to it, reloading you with a half a second to register that you just died before you have to start moving again. And they are pretty unforgiving to mistakes.
-"Easy" mode is a lie lol. I'm not sure what the other difficulties change but if you are not great at videogames you might just want to watch a playthrough of this instead.

The single most overhyped metroidvania I've ever played. The gameplay is extremely bland, there's little to explore, and the story is just uninteresting. The game constantly throws names of things, people, and places at you and expects you to care because they're not there anymore  or whatever. If you don't save right after a cutscene or dialogue, you have to watch it all over again for no good reason. Especially annoying because you get a limited number of saves through your mana bar. That same mana bar is used for some exploration abilities, actively discouraging you from exploring the game or trying interesting things without savescumming if it fails. You can also very easily get stuck in long sequences because the game decides not to offer you any mana crystals in that section. Combat is offensively bad, you get one button to spam (technically some mana-based abilities as well, but they suck balls) and then you just dodge enemy attack patterns. But the best strategy is to look for some sort of highground where enemies can't hit you and just spam your attack until they're dead. Then you save, and that's all the combat challenge gone from that section.

Just play hollow knight or la mulana if you want an interesting metroidvania to play.

Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition

After playing this game again to remind myself of the story before playing the sequel, I quickly remembered why I hate it. Yes, the art and music are fantastic and the movement feels fluid and satisfying, but this game is filled to the brim with bullshit.

Instant death traps come in all forms. Some spikes will instantly kill you even though they look identical to other spikes that only damage you. Some parts of the ceiling will drop a block on you before you can even register its movement, and are slightly shadowed so they're difficult to notice, especially since Ori himself draws so much attention with his bright color. Some walls have laser beams that fire periodically, while having a noticeable but very brief warning beforehand, and dodging them can sometimes be difficult due to some rather slippery controls.

There's also a few chase sections in which you must escape an approaching threat (that instantly kills you if touched) by using the skills you've obtained to navigate through a sort of obstacle course. These scenes almost always involve some level of trial and error, since additional obstacles will be thrown at you from offscreen leaving you with a fraction of a second to react. These sections are extremely difficult to complete without either foreknowledge or insanely fast reaction time. Combine this with platforming segments that give absolutely no room for even the slightest error, and you've got a recipe for frustration.

On top of all of this, death sends you back to your last save point. Designated save point shrines are scattered throughout the world, but they're sparse. The only way to save your progress outside of those is by expending a small amount of your energy resource to drop a "Soul Link." Now, energy refills aren't too uncommon and you can quickly increase your maximum capacity, but still - what if you're out of energy, or just forget to save for a while? Suddenly you get obliterated by something you couldn't see coming and several minutes of progress has just been erased in the blink of an eye. Now you have to go and grab all those collectibles all over again. That's nice and fair!

I could go over the metroidvania collection and exploration aspect, or the story presentation, or the sound design, or any other of the game's really good aspects, but for me they're almost entirely overshadowed by obnoxious hazards that require pixel-perfect execution to avoid and the near-constant annoyance of cheap deaths.

An average platformer that pretends to be a metroidvania. Stuff I particularly disliked:

1.Save system is basically "save scumming" as a mechanic. It reinforces this by forcing several unskippable cutscenes that, if you happen to forget to save immediately afterward, are forced to watch all over again should you die soon after. There are quite a few of these instances.
2. Many ledges/environmental hazards don't match their model so you'll fall off or take damage without actually touching them. There's also a questionable amount of instant death traps hidden all over.
3. Aerial control is at times very sloppy and almost seems like there's an input delay for the sake of not breaking progression too much.
4. Enemies are pretty much just a button-mashing game. There's no learning involved, just spam M1 (or in the later half, press M2 once or twice). Also, there's no boss encounters. Instead, you get "escape the area" timed events that have gotcha one-shots you can't reasonably know are there on the first run-through that immediately send you back to the start of the escape event. Basically, just stuff to waste your time and frustrate you.
5. Extremely short game. I got this on sale, but damn would I be disappointed if I bought this for the full price.

Game looks nice, though in some areas the bloom effects are so bright you can barely see what is happening around you. Play Hollow Knight instead, it's a better game in all regards.

The opening cutscene is one of the most beautiful works of art in the entire history of video games.  It's "first ten minutes of Up" good.  The art throughout the entire game is gorgeous.  The music is very good.  The atmosphere is very good, I love the game world.

The gameplay just doesn't hold up.  It's fun in a number of areas.  But far, far too many places in this game expect you to do things that are not just unintuitive, but anti-intuitive.  I've been confused in games before, gotten stuck, figured it out, enjoyed the whole experience for what it was, even when it was frustrating at times.  I know how that goes.  This is different.  The game artists should get to legally give the level/gameplay designers a wedgie for a full calendar year after what they did to their baby.

It's frankly strange to see just how botched and amateurish the level/gameplay design is when the whole thing is so gorgeous, well-presented, and otherwise polished.  With about a third of the game left to go, I'm going to finish it, but I expect it to be a slog that's mostly unfun with occasional patches of fun, which I'm going through in the hopes that the ending is even a tenth as beautiful as the beginning.

I was not sure whether to press thumbs up/down on this review. Furthermore, i was also very excited to give a review. 


---WHAT I LIKED---
I do love the visuals of the game, the story, the colours, the environments. I do find certain elements of the game very fun. The music is nice. The animation is really good.

---WHAT I DID NOT LIKE---
Although for me it lacked personality. There is not many interesting things going on in this game. Some of the platforming is made a bit wonky. There is at certain areas, maybe a bit too much effects in the background which makes the non linear character hard to see. Some elements in the environment such as the spike areas, are hard to notice due to the same issue.
There is no variety of music either. Despite that the music is really beautiful, for the price it is at, i expect more diversity in the soundtracks variations. This is more of a personal opinion on the music. 
There was this area with flooding, the character has to escape to the very top of the tree. I did this first try, surprisingly. I guess it is because when i was playing this game, i only played it to get over with it, as I could not enjoy it any further.
I also noticed while going through a lot of pain to do many things that was required for next step, there was no reward system integrated.
 I really was playing only because i did all this "effort", and when i DO get an upgrade, i am not able to adapt to the new ability as quickly due to the design of the game. 
Another thing to add, i was not a fan of the narrative. It is not for me personally. I enjoy quiet narratives, i however did not find the voice over as interesting as i should of.


---OVERALL---
I wish i could have enjoyed this game as much as everyone else did. I tried really hard to get into it. I kept on playing it or even probably at this point was forcing myself to play it, until i realised it's really not my type of game. I do see a lot of space for improvement and a lot of flaws in the game play and environment. 

At the end of the day, i also tried to enjoy the experience as much as i could.

 This however does not mean the game is not worthy of checking out :)). It was just not my cup of tea.

"Ori and the Blind Forest," developed by Moon Studios, is a visually stunning action-platformer that combines challenging gameplay with an emotionally powerful story. You play as Ori, a guardian spirit, navigating a beautifully crafted forest to save it from decay.

The game features tight, responsive controls and a variety of abilities that make exploration and combat deeply satisfying. Its hand-painted artwork, meticulously animated character performances, and fully orchestrated soundtrack create an immersive and emotional experience.

Pros:

-Gorgeous hand-painted visuals and animation.
-Tight, responsive controls and fluid gameplay.
-Emotional and compelling narrative.
-Beautifully orchestrated soundtrack.

Cons:

-High difficulty may frustrate some players.
-Relatively short game.

Overall, "Ori and the Blind Forest" is a breathtaking and emotionally resonant platformer thatâ€™s a must-play for fans of the genre. 9/10

Cons:

This is one of my most favorite games of all time. The world is so magical, and has so much depth. The artwork will blow you away every chance it gets, and so will the extraordinary soundtrack. The story may be a bit cheezy, yes, but I guarantee you that even the first few minutes will hit you right in the soul (unless you don't have one, of course). Also, Ori is the cutest little critter to ever walk the earth. Anything that hurts him, hurts me even more. And of course, ANYTHING will hurt him. Little man will explode if he twists his ankle.

That being said, beating the game on One Life mode was one of the most satisfying video game challenges I've completed, and I would do it again in a heartbeat. It's also not quite as hard as some people make it out to be, as the real challenge doesn't come from how hard it is not to make a mistake, but how much the game punishes you for making that mistake. I on my first play-through of the game, I died hundreds of times, my next play-though of the game was on hard mode, and even on hard mode I died significantly less. Because this is a game you can learn, and you will be able to very clearly see the progress of that learning as you play, because it doesn't matter how much the game punishes you for making a mistake if you don't make it in the first place. The more you learn the game, the less mistakes you'll make, and it will feel SO good. All the game wants from you is perfection, and with enough patience and practice, you WILL be able to do it, and it will feel amazing.

Artistically, this game is a masterpiece, and there are moments so gorgeous and so creative that it will take your breath away. As someone who loves artsy games, there are times I love it so much that it hurts. I wholeheartedly recommend joining Ori on his heroic journey to restore this forest, and I wish you all the luck possible in not dying immediately.  :)

"Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition" falls short of its promise to deliver a captivating and enchanting gaming experience, ultimately failing to live up to the high expectations set by its predecessor.

One of the most glaring issues with the game is its difficulty curve. While a certain level of challenge can be expected in a platformer, "Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition" takes it to an extreme, with frustratingly precise platforming sections and punishing combat encounters that feel more like exercises in frustration than tests of skill. The game's unforgiving checkpoints only serve to exacerbate the problem, forcing players to repeatedly replay difficult sections until they get them just right.

The story, which should be a highlight of any narrative-driven game, is similarly underwhelming. While the game attempts to tug at players' heartstrings with its tale of friendship and sacrifice, it ultimately falls flat due to its predictable plot twists and lack of emotional depth. Characters are one-dimensional and forgettable, with little in the way of development or nuance to make them truly compelling.

Graphically, the game is a mixed bag. While the hand-drawn art style is undeniably beautiful and atmospheric, the visuals can be overly busy and cluttered at times, making it difficult to discern important details during intense platforming sequences. Performance issues are also common, with frequent frame rate drops and stuttering that detract from the overall experience.

Even the "Definitive Edition" enhancements, which promise improved visuals and additional content, fail to impress. While the new areas and abilities are a welcome addition, they do little to address the game's core issues and ultimately feel tacked on and unnecessary.

In the end, "Ori and the Blind Forest: Definitive Edition" is a disappointing follow-up to the original game that fails to recapture the magic of its predecessor. Its punishing difficulty, lackluster story, and technical issues make it a hard game to recommend to anyone other than the most dedicated platforming enthusiasts.

So I bought the game in 2022, finished it and felt pretty good about it. The artstyle was good, gameplay was alright, phenomenal music. Out of curiosity, I decided to reinstall the game today, and start a new playthrough. 4 hours later on the same day, my emotional ass was staring at the end credits feeling like a new person. While the combat may seem lackluster, as you upgrade your skill tree and imporve your arsenal, it does get quite fun to see just how powerful the game lets you become. The movement is incredibly satisfying, with the most fluid parkour animations I have ever seen in a game, as well as the controls feeling genuinely amazing to use. The soundtrack is nothing short of a fucking masterpiece, with a phenomenal story accompanied by said soundtrack. It's a metroidvania, so it (of course) has a metroidvania-style gameplay loop with exploration and backtracking, and permanent ability unlocks. I don't know why the game was so unmemorable to me on my first run two years ago, but I could not recommend this enough, everybody deserves to experience this game at least once.

Oh, and buy the sequel too, it's even better!

[h1]Frustrating Console Platform Jumper with a Meaningless Story[/h1]

I sometimes enjoy a good console-like side scrolling action platformer. Unfortunately this is not one of those times. I got Ori on sale and even then it's not worth the price. The story is vague and rather pointless, as it leans HEAVILY on mood and forced emotion rather than any real meaning. Completely void of any sort of noteworthy storytelling. And to add insult to injury, the areas you travel are a rehash of the old wind/fire/water elemental theme, except with trees and some sort of ancient spirit whatever. Really Moon Studios? Weak.

And as is the trend of these modern platformers, they love to punish you for not knowing thing in advance. Literally (yes, literally) they'll crush you for no reason other than to satisfy the need for a character power. Honestly it feels like they added powers and the mechanics they achieve first, then built the worlds around this to gate your progression. If I'm forced to travel in a specific path through your maze, at least give me some direction. The worst mechanic of this is tying save points to an expendable resource. And if you make a poor choice in where you save before a particularly annoying gauntlet of pointless hurdles, you're doomed to either try over and over again to get through it or rage quit.

The only challenge is from timing jumps perfectly, often with the addition of a timer aspect such as projectiles thrown at you, boulders rolling down towards you, doorways closing, etc. Pointless obstacles and platform jumping with no meaning for them existing otherr than to keep progressing is rather dull.

Don't get me wrong though, as the graphics are fun, the music is amazing, and animations are buttery smooth. So this had a ton of potential at its core, but was put into the hands of amateur storytellers and level designers. My top complaint on the gameplay mechanics itself is that positioning my character while jumping is a bit too twitchy. Otherwise everything is good at the game's core. In short, the level design and story is Ori's downfall.

I bought Ori and the Blind Forest + Ori and the Will of the Wisps in sale after I played No Rest For The Wicked, because I wanted to taste more from Moon studios and I never got my hands on Ori before. I must say that it was a pleasant surprise for me to find out how good these games are.

I love the aesthetics of the game, the story, the gameplay... everything. 

Pros:
+ Visuals (It's so charming and mesmerising)
+ Story (I love how story is told through scenes more than through words)
+ Soundtrack (It hits the right spots everytime)
+ Puzzles (It excels as a puzzle platformer)
+ Abilities (I like that every ability has it's use, nothing is just to fill the roster)
+ Level design (Level are interconnected and pretty well designed)

Cons:
- Gameplay sometimes (Sometimes Ori feels a little bit stiff and rough around the edges, gameplaywise)

The roughness is the only thing I can criticise on this game, because Ori and the Blind Forest is nearly perfect puzzle platformer and one of the best I've ever played.

I first played Ori and the Will of the Wisps before I found out that it was a sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest.

I heard The Blind Forest was harder than Will of the Wisps but I disagree. This game gets you used to the game mechanics of the world and while the wall climbing can be difficult once you've played it for a little while you do get used to it.

The world of The Blind Forest is interactive so looking around and seeing how you can use the environment is going to be a big help. The most challenging part of both games are the chase sequences which, I'm not going to lie, are not my favourite. However if you can get them down in this one they shouldn't be too bad in WotW. The sequel also has bosses so, again, I do think it is better to get the basics down in this one first.

Lastly, and should have been first really, is the story, music and graphics of this world. It really is beautiful. Playing backwards I was still able to appreciate Ori's beginnings before the events of WotW and I don't think it matters which way you play the two games, the story is beautiful either way and I quite liked learning how the characters in WotW came together after already getting to know them.

Entertainment: 36/40
 + One of the greatest movement systems I have played with.
 + Makes you want to 100% not for the bragging rights, but instead as an excuse to play more.
 + This game differs from most of its genera where it puts the platforming before the combat and it made me realize just how fun that can be.

Design: 17/20
 + It has what very well may be both the most creative and satisfying platforming ability I have had the pleasure of using in the form of Bash. Oh my God... Bash.
 + Almost every upgrade you find can be used as a movement tool, so you are able to string together some really nutty actions.
 + Your base movement speed is higher then it typically would be in a game like this. Pair that with the enhanced movement and you can zip around like a fly on crack.
 + Has some really creative platforming sections.
 + While there were no dedicated boss fights, they made up by having these super cool "escape sequences" that hold the fastest and most difficult platforming in the game.
 - Although you can do some super impressive movements with your abilities, your base jump is pretty wimpy.
 - Some walls are pretty slippery and can be annoying to vault up and off of.
 - "Energy" economy was weird. Started out the game having to scrounge for resources, but ended it not even having to care. That could very well have been intentional, but I was not a big fan of the first few moments due to that.
 - There are switches that you have to slam into and many of them you need to do so multiple times which only slowed it down.
 - A few secrets feel archaic and uncalled for.
 - Combat was largely enjoyable as a whole.

Presentation: 19/20
 + I mean, just look at it.
 + Not only is it a beautiful game to look at, it is a highly stylized game at that so the beauty is 
 + Intractables are very clear, allowing them to be easily used on instinct.
 + The music was simply great. I was already listening to it on its own before I even beat the game.
 + Sound effects were good, though there was notion that I need so stop an listen to.
 + A very clean and effective UI.
 - While Interactables are easy to spot, hazards are less prominent and can sneak up on you.
 - I suspect that Kuro, the main antagonist, was animated differently from the rest of the cast, leading her to stick out like a sore thumb.


Story: 14/20

Ori and the Blind Forest.. is not a game. It is a work of art. The visuals are stunning, the soundtrack so touching it made me cry even from a main menu track, the story is beautiful (though sad at times), and the gameplay is not that bad for me as a newbie to platformers, though new players will find the first tough situation (you will know it when you get there) a serious challenge.

This isn't a good game, which is a shame. Based on the reviews I thought that this was some amazing metroidvenia/platformer with some amazing story and aesthetics.
While we can safely say the art style, graphics and music are ethereal on the surface, they have a huge problem. Everything is dialed up to eleven without consideration to its necessity.

Everything is vividly colored, nicely textured there are nice effects of explosions and foreground/background elements. It just looks amazing, but it is horrible to play. Half the time some element of the scene obscures the enemy, obscures their projectiles or the player just flat out can't see what is next.
Ori dies in a couple of hits from the enemies, and in one or two from traps. Health pickups are rare so the player will often will be running around at the brink of death anyways
This compared with the atrocious floaty controls, the "mash the x button and pray, while trying to dodge the bullet hell" combat makes the game infuriating.

This isn't a platformer or a story rich game. This is essentially a long gauntlet of traps and obstacles that are designed to kill you. Right from the start you have to make pixel perfect jumps, dodge enemy bullets and traverse long sections of what can only be described as trickshots to get to the next story point. Meanwhile, everything, and I mean everything is trying to kill you. Every section of the map is filled with brambles, laser beans, respawning monsters or some other nasty trap.
The brash mechanic sounds nice, looks cool, but they rely on it too much. Oh my, why do you have to put in long sections where the only way of traversal is to basically catch every projectile with brash, double jump, pray that the next projectile comes in time, time another brash... It is just bad.

In Hollow Knight you have such sections, but most of them are completely optional or there is more than one way to solve them. You have such high skill actions like brash, the pogo, but that is optional. Here it is mandatory. 

There are some good ideas here, but the execution is terrible. I often felt that the game is hard, because otherwise it would have been too short, there isn't really much substance here. So the game was made hard, but then they realized it was too hard so they added the self save feature. Now the game could have become too easy, so they don't give you energy. Now you can't really use your energy for anything else, but saving otherwise you can (but will anyways), get into situations where you just somehow have to make an impossible sequence happen, because there is no other option.

Given the problems with the controls, the ruthlessness of traps and enemies, contrasted with the beautiful music and art style, the game is exceptionally dissonant. Angelic music plays while Ori gets destroyed by everything. My mind wants to relax to be tensed up by the gameplay, resulting in a very frustrating experience overall.

Celeste is better for platforming, Dead Cells is better for combat and Hollow Knight is just flat out better overall.

## Score
Some people will love this game but I am not one of those people and as such I cannot recommend it. To start off this game is hard, like really hard. At the end I had over 600 deaths and while many of those can be attributed to me not playing many platformers most were just bc this game requires your movement to be precise and most things are one shots.

### Gameplay
I don't like the gameplay of this game. I had so many bugs and glitches that it made it less fun to play. Many of the talent tree options just didn't work and I felt like I wasted hard earned points. In addition to that I had many bugs where inputs would not register which would cause me to die. The combat felt like a worse version of Hollow Knight were it was basic and did not feel fluid.

### Story
meh

### Art
This game is beautiful. All of the background art is hand drawn which can cause problems gameplay wise. But artistically it is gorgeous, navigating the environment with a hand drawn image behind you. The music score also brings so much life to the game especially during the escape sequences.

To all those of you who are interested in 100%ing this game's achievements. When you are going for the 'Unhinged' achievement, DO NOT restart a run on the same save file after you die. The game will tell you you're on One-Life difficulty and the save file will say One-Life but the game no longer considers it as a One-Life playthrough due to a bug. Delete the save file after you die and start a new one from scratch. I had to play through this whole game without dying TWICE just because a bug screwed me out of my achievement and if I can save just one of you from making that mistake then this review was worth writing.

This game is brilliant, from a pure platformer perspective, one of the best in the genre. The music and world is so beautiful. The controls are so tight, and so many movement options that need precise timing. Ori just moves around the map weaving around the plethora of enemy projectiles flying towards you. This game doesn't really have a "combat" system per say, you just go near the enemies and spam a close range spirit attack. Ori 2 adds a full blown combat system but Ori 1 mainly focuses on the platforming aspects. 

Definitely play this before moving on to Ori Will of the Wisps because that game improves upon every aspect and it's hard to go back to this one afterwards.

I've finished the game (on XSX) and it's a mixed bag. There is satisfaction when you finish some difficult section. Especially 3 escape sequences.

However this is also a game with most moronic save system ever invented - you have to spend energy point to create save point. You may ask: what's wrong with that? Unless you played the game before there is no way to predict where is the optimal place to save. Very often you will "lock" yourself long before difficult section, with no energy to save and low health. That means tons of repetitive, boring grind to finally make a "miracle run" and push further. You will waste hours of your life on pointless replays, especially in early game. Did I mention that saves use the same energy pool as attacks? Yes. It is THAT stupid...

I don't mind difficulty. I don't mind required precision and reflex. I don't mind learning levels and timing. I'm giving this game a "no" [b]because of broken save and health system[/b]. If you play the game you will know what I mean - there are difficult games with good flow made of chain of well-designed challenges with autosaves between them. But here challenge (that is good on its own!) may become boring torment because you accidentally approached it on bad terms.

I just finished Ori and the Blind Forest.  And as always, it's time for a game review.  

I'll start this simple enough and say that this game is a work of art!  Everything that was done in this game was done with a lot of love.  The music, the visuals, the story, the controls, everything is expertly and beautifully done.  The devs put their heart and soul into this one.  Someone looked at the Metroidvania genre and said "Let's make this beautiful".  That's not to say that other games in the genre aren't wonderful, but the devs of Ori were on a mission for this one.  And I really appreciate how approachable this game is.  The difficulty scales well with the game and while there are very challenging moments, nothing feels frustrating.  Also, the end of the game isn't the end of the game.  You really do want 100% this game.  And it's not all that difficult to do.  The main game took me about 15 hours to go through, and that was with some exploring but not a whole lot.  

The only thing I will say for people who have not played this is to know what to expect as you approach it.  The first, the story is a heart wrencher.  Like Pixar level heart breaking story.  The other is that this is not a game where you are a badass space bounty hunter, vampire hunter, or insect with a sword.  You're a gentle woodland spirit, and the game play reflects that.  So if you're expecting frantic combat game play, this is not that game.  Neither of those things are a negative.  You should just know what you're getting into.

Ultimately, Ori and the Blind Forest is absolutely worth the full price.  So go out there and play this one!

Lows outweighed the highs.

I'm very conflicted with how I feel about this game.  On one hand, it has very stunning visuals, beautiful music, and a neat story at the start.  But then on the other hand, you have unforgiving chase scenes, a story that later loses its grip, and moments that make you wonder if the game was QA'd.  Overall I think 4.5/10 is my actual rating.

It had a really strong start, and I wish the effort that went into that carried throughout the rest of the game.  But it doesn't.  The story fades, and at the end I didn't even realize I had beaten it.  Leveling up doesn't matter since enemies/thorns get equally as strong too.  And thorns are EVERYWHERE for no reason.  The lowest points for me were by far the boss chase scenes.  If you die you have to start the whole chase scene over again.  And there's no way you could beat a chase scene without either A} dying a million times to learn what to do or B} having knowledge beforehand on where to go or what random rock is about to spike you from the sky.

In conclusion it wasn't a bad game, but definitely missed it's potential to be Hollow Knight status.  The lows outweighed the highs and for that reason I don't want to play it again nor would I recommend it to my wife.

Genuinely one of the most frustrating platformers I've ever played. I'm a big fan of "difficult" games, Dark souls, Hollow Knight, Elden Ring, etc. But this game's platforming and floating controls make it very difficult to actually enjoy, and the mechanic where players can choose where to save, while interesting and sometimes fun, and can also be very annoying, especially since it's tied to unlocking certain areas and also using special attacks. Balancing all those mechanics with the save system can make it difficult and frustrating to save at times, especially when traversing through difficult platforming sections. I've also found the game not very intuitive at times, which can lead to annoying sections where you die on repeat due to confusing sections of the game. Not to mention the artificial difficulty of many enemies. I actually quite enjoyed the enemy variety, the way the enemies and their attacks were blended into the platforming was actually quite cool, but I didn't enjoy the ridiculous tankiness of a lot of the enemies, which is made even worse by the frustrating placement and lack of move variety of the enemies. 

Overall a very frustrating and annoying game, the story seems really good, and the art is absolutely beautiful, but all of that is ruined by the rest of the game mechanics and ridiculous punishments for slight slip ups, (why does everything do so much damage so quickly? The lack of Iframes is confusing to say  the least) Chances are you might enjoy the game, I certainly did at times, but the overall experience was negative. I'm looking forward to any changes in the sequel.

A great matroidvania platformer with fantastic art style and soundtrack.
I really loved the the platforming of this game. It requires just the right amount of precision and creative use of your given abilities. The main character Ori moves with great fluidity and the movement animation is just pristine.
You will die A LOT in this game, but I find the challenge to be fun and fair. Since you can save almost anywhere in the game, it also doesn't become tedious since you can try again right away.
The "boss fights" comes in the form of long escape sequences, which requires even greater precision. Since you are required to start from the beginning of these sessions, some may find these sessions too difficult or tedious. I personally really enjoyed these sequences and found them to be the highlight of the game by far.
I played the original version first and then the definitive edition. The definitive edition adds two new areas with two new abilities along with a lot of QoL improvements, such as fast travel. The new abilities gives more freedom in the platforming and provides more solutions. However, since the other areas are not remade to accommodate for these new abilities, they sometimes trivialize some sections of the game. In that sense, I found the original game to be tighter on the platforming front.
The atmosphere of the game is phenomenal, with orchestral music paired with a unique and polished art style. Some of the cut scenes, enhanced by the somber music, are real tear-jerkers.
Would recommend to anyone who enjoys challenging platforming.

This is a good, not a great game, but it has some serious stuff I hated.

The good: it's a beautifully realized world and exploration is generally fun, especially when you get all the traversal powers. There are some good puzzles that never took too long and blended with the platforming. You can save practically anywhere you want. You move quick enough and there are fast travel points that generally make re-visiting locations painless, except the water tree.

The bad: first, this is a pretty hardcore platformer disguised as a metroidvania. All those health upgrades and spirit upgrades don't mean anything in the many instant kill escape sequences, or to all the lava or even dirty water. It is also sometimes very unclear where to run when the murderous owl instant kills you for a single wrong step. This was on EASY! Maybe because I didn't start the game on easy.

It's a long stretch to reach the start of the game, and it involves you sometimes moving a character sometimes not. We don't need to slowly crawl, just show it. Similarly, at the end of the game you move a character a few feet and that's all you had to do. Just have the character show up.

There's a lot of ambiguity around what you can climb, what will hurt you, what will kill you, and fighting enemies is easy but a cluster of light that you can't really tell what is going on. Many sequences require you to keep enemies alive to "bash" them, which is a traversal mechanic that probably should have stayed using static objects. Being able to throw enemies is sometimes fun though.

There's also no bosses to speak of. The platforming core of the game comes through when you have escape sequences that are quite tough.

Finally, the story: [spoiler]The villain is the hero. Seriously, that light tree loses a leaf and because of that murders 3 baby owls. Why did that happen? That's a real jerk move on the part of the magic tree, and it doesn't even get Ori back. So Kuro taking the tree's power seems reasonable to me. Then when she sees all the danger and destruction she's caused she returns it and dies. Those tree spirits seem to come back to life, but not Kuro's babies.[/spoiler]

The game is a beauty. It introduces its concepts in fun ways. The game play is engaging and the story is a wonder. That's not to mention the graphics, which my lord, are some of the best on Steam. If you are to get some sort of platformer, this is such a good one to start on.

The platforming was smooth and kinetic, particularly chaining jumps through the bash technique. 

Exploration was fun with the movement based unlocks, but after 4 energy and a similar amount of health I didn't find much marginal benefit from further character upgrades. 

Combat largely felt like an afterthought, it didn't feel particularly necessary. The save system was generous and flexible, which I appreciated with how easy it was to die in the many platforming sections. The boss battle-esque escape sequences were the only parts I found frustrating due to the mix of easy death, sense of time pressure, and lack of midway saves.
