Review written after 38,8h.

This is one of the prettiest 2D/2.5D games I've ever played. A perfect game for the youngest, although the production can be irritating with its screwdriver. The story is not very ambitious but perfect for a younger audience.

Advantages:
- The game lasts for a good 13h, but this time can be shortened if you do not collect all the items that strengthen the main character of OIR.
- High level of difficulty despite choosing it.
- The best element of this part are the escape sequences - uncompromising level of difficulty.
- Character development elements - primitive simple three upgrade paths that can be maxed out at the end of the game.
- The organic nature of the levels - I will sum it up with these words - Once you play this platformer, you will never want to play or look at primitive and angular platformers.
- The narrator of the story is a nice addition, he does not stop the gameplay and speaks in a language invented by the creators.

Defects:
- The further you go into the forest, the more damage the spikes and flames cause. - Why don't they deal gogantic damage from the very beginning? (The sequel is also the same.)
- Achievements such as complete the game in 3h. should not exist - Maybe I would turn a blind eye to it if the game were terribly linear, but it is not.
- Four different difficulty levels - If there are more than three difficulty levels then the challenge is equivalent in every game.

Final Rating: 7/10.

Ori and the Blind Forest clearly resonates with a lot of people, and there's some good to be found hereâ€”the visuals are pleasing, the music is generally good (although I found the constant interweaving of the main theme into every track a little tiresome), and there are sections where, once you get the platforming down, it feels really good.

However, I can't really bring myself to recommend this game.

There's a certain sense of "imprecision" to the controls at times which is kind of hard to explain (but which other reviewers have attested to already). For instance, there are a few places where you need to jump onto a pillar or other raised spot, and in most platformers, you'd just press in the direction of the raised spot and jump on it, but in Ori, you'll automatically jump *away* from the thing you're trying to jump on. It's not especially hard to make such jumps once you're aware of this, but it's counterintuitive and fussier than it ought to be. In general, it feels like the controls aren't designed to deal with the moments where you need to make a precise landing, and although the game is pretty generous with checkpoints (since it lets you make your own almost anywhere at the cost of some of your "mana"), I felt like I was dying a little more often than I should have been.

The combat isn't really a high point of the game. Ori defenders will say that the game "isn't about combat," and to some extent, that's true (since there's more of a focus on exploration and precision platforming)... but it still *contains* plenty of combat, and it's not very good. Mostly you'll be just spamming the same homing attack over and over at a short distance from the enemy. You eventually get the ability to repel certain projectiles back at enemies, which is kind of cool, but it's not enough to turns things around, and the wimpy homing attack is still going to be your go-to at times, even as the enemies become total damage sponges in the late game.

I think my biggest issue, though, is that the visuals, while beautiful to a spectator, don't always communicate information to the player as clearly as they could. Some enemies shoot projectiles that will leave fire or some other hazardous stuff on a platform, but it doesn't always stick out as clearly from the background as it could. There's one area late in the game where a slightly dull-colored water turns out to be acid that kills you instantly, but it's only slightly dull in appearance (and not, like, bubbly and bright green and flagrantly unsafe to touch). Heated floors that damage you as you stand on them are a little too subtle in their glowing animation; the first time you get hurt by them, it feels like a bit too much of a surprise. During the "escape sequences" at certain points, where the game switches heavily to a precision platforming focus (which, again, the controls don't always feel quite suited to), I had several points where I wasn't sure where I was supposed to jump next, and because I missed the narrow two-second window when I was supposed to do whatever, I died and had to repeat that section. It doesn't help that some of the encroaching hazards, like the rising water in the first escape sequence, actually move *faster* if you're doing better, taking away whatever extra time you would have otherwise gotten to think through the next step; this sort of "rubber-banding" feels antithetical to the design of a good escape sequence. Once you get those sections down, the flow feels pretty good, but it felt like I had to slog through too many "gotcha" moments for me to get there.

All this being said, there are clearly plenty of people who really like this game, and your mileage may certainly vary. I wouldn't say it's bad; it's just full of too many little annoyances that start to add up by the end, and having completed it once, I don't think I'll be going back to it again.

If your game is on slowmotion, just either play the game on vsync off or you jump into Nvidia control panel and find Manage 3d Settings > Program settings > find "Ori and the blind forest" and under "Specify the settings for this program" put Vertical Sync as "Adaptive". If the problem continues, additionally to this, find "Max frame rate" and put the frame rate to 30 fps. Game will work like it should be after.

A captivating story unfolds alongside stunning visuals in Ori and the Blind Forest. The hand-drawn world comes alive on the Steam Deck, making every frame a feast for the eyes. The mesmerizing soundtrack perfectly complements the atmosphere, further enriching the experience.
While the game is ideal for grabbing and playing in short bursts, be prepared for time to melt away as you get engrossed in Ori's journey. However, it's important to note that the challenging platforming might require some adjustment for newcomers to the genre. Easy mode is a great option for those unfamiliar with this style of gameplay.
Even if you're not a die-hard fan of platformers, Ori and the Blind Forest is a masterpiece worth owning, especially when on sale. The combination of its enchanting story, breathtaking visuals, and captivating soundtrack makes it an unforgettable experience.

The game uses movement-based progression (subjective) like hollow knight, metroid demon's crest etc. Essentially, as you progress in the game, you get more abilities that help you traverse the game. However, some of the abilities just lose their usability and only exist to bar you from certain areas.

The Gameplay
The game is a platformer, do not focus on the combat; the combat is pretty bland and repetitive. You're playing this game for the platforming
Personally I didn't find the platforming as hard as I wanted it to be. If you aren't very well versed in platformers ~~or don't particularly like them~~, you'll probably enjoy the game more.
The difficulty setting only affects the damage you take, so there isn't much of a difference between the difficulties depending on how good you are.
The game is also VERY forgiving. You can save almost wherever you are, making it a great platformer for beginners

[i] Ori and the Blind Forest [/i] is a game that combines fairy tale aesthetics with hardcore Metroidvania gameplay; its art is unquestionably supreme, and its level design is horrifyingly hellish. Do not get me wrong, because I liked the gameplay a lot. What I mean by 'horrifyingly hellish' is that the level design consists of so many different kinds of puzzles and traps that there is not a single one-for-all solution for the challenges presented in the game. Jumping and running without thinking won't help you no matter how many skills you unlock. You have to constantly observe situations and adapt accordingly, which is without a doubt a solid proof of the excellent craftsmanship of the developers. I can see that they are seriously committed to the best of the best gameplay experiences they can offer.

That being said, this game has pretty straight-forward, and fairly predictable storyline. The developers did their best to maximize the dramatic effect of the story with their supreme art style and excellent camerawork, but the story itself is nothing special. Maybe this was intentional because this simplicity of the writing makes the audience feel like reading a fairy tale. Still, it's a solid conclusion that they did not invest as much effort into the writing of this game.

If you are looking for a game featuring the greatest kind of Metroidvania gameplay experience with stunning visuals, I recommend this game without a moment's hesitation. If you are someone just wanting to chill out and relax, go find some other game. This game might look all sweet and kind on its cover, but beneath it lurks a monstrosity ready to pressure your brain in every direction at the earliest opportunities; challenge it only when you are ready to fight.

[h1]Quality on every front, flowered with incredible amounts of beautiful charm.[/h1] 

Ori and the Blind Forest is a great gameplay, aesthetic and story experience. There is not much lacking in Moon Studiosâ€™ metroidvania. 

The story follows Ori and Naru living a quiet, undisturbed life somewhere deep in the forest of Nibel. Once the forest [strike]starts dying[/strike] goes blind and does not bear fruit anymore, Ori leaves his only family and embarks on a journey to save the magical woods. While he makes new friends, he does also brave many dangers and the gameâ€™s main antagonist - Kuro. 
The game has a few cutscenes. Sein is guiding our character through the game and the narrator that is supposed to be the light-god I guess, gives the broader context of the world. But beside him and Sein speaking in their funky language that is just subtitled on the screen, there is not much dialogue. Even if itâ€™s just a few cutscenes and the story is not that long, the careful combination of music and aesthetic makes the way how it is presented a very beautiful plot. 
While ultimately the story revolves around the idea of maternal love, I also view it as a parallel to good and bad. One of the interpretations of the Yin-Yang motive you can make is that even in the absolute evil you will find a crumb of good and vice versa. The idea that the darkness is evil and the light is good loses its meaning once given proper context and perspective. 

Oriâ€™s moveset starts with simple jumps, but with time it evolves into a very dynamic and flexible system. While the game doesnâ€™t do anything too original besides the bash, an ability letting you bounce off enemies and their projectiles in whatever direction you want resetting your double jump, the quality of all the moves and how you can chain them in combos makes platforming with Ori very enjoyable. The game rewards skill and thoughtful usage of its moveset. 
Throughout the map you can find several types of collectibles â€“ life cells, energy cells as well as experience and free ability points. The skill tree branches into 3 paths â€“ combat, utility and efficiency. Leveling and unlocking the new abilities is fun and useful. 
In terms of combat, it starts with this weak flame homing-missile attack. Progressing through the game rewards you with stomp and charge jump. Once you unlock these the game encourages you to mix those attacks together in explosive combos, because the basic attack, even if upgraded, can take too long to kill the endgame enemies. 

The game looks amazing, the hand-painted environments, playing with colors and shadows makes this production a very aesthetic and eye-pleasing experience. Any screenshot of this game could be my wallpaper. 
The sound design has the proper oompf!, you can feel the power surging when you level up or smite the enemies or stomp your way forward. But the gameâ€™s score is something else. I needed to look up a fancy, new word to describe the music for that game â€“ and itâ€™s [b][i]amazeballs[/i][/b] it seems. Itâ€™s a great part of this productionâ€™s identity and success. It complements the aesthetic and story of this game perfectly. Fav tracks would be [i]Up the Spirit Caverns Walls[/i], [i]Returning to the Spirit Tree[/i] and [i]Light of Nibel[/i] as it is the ending theme of course. 

The definitive edition adds two new areas to explore and two new abilities for you to utilize. Additionally, it makes some quality-of-life improvements and adds some general polish to the game. 

I can for sure say that Ori and the Blind Forest is one of the most beautiful games Iâ€™ve ever played. Its picturesque graphics, amazing soundtrack, moving story and enjoyable platforming make this production worth playing for everyone. The gameâ€™s level of quality shows itself on every front, with every aspect of the game being at least very good. You can really feel talented hearts put into this work. 
Also it seems like a good starter for somebody new to video games. Engaging, easy to learn-hard to master and it does not require some crazy tier hardware.

I enjoyed most of this game and completed it, but I wouldn't recommend it to other players, especially those over 40, as there are a few chase levels/areas where you need to get every jump right or it's insta-death and you are taken back to the very beginning of the level.

These levels required dozens of attempts for me and it spoiled my overall enjoyment of the game - especially the final level, where after I finally beat it, my feeling was simply thank **** that's over, and I didn't connect with the games ending at all because of that, and I won't be replaying it.

i enjoyed hollow knight, and I was looking for a metroidvania, if your in the same boat as me and you are wondering if this game is better or worse or a lil bit like hollow knight il talk about it. I also bought the bundle which comes with both the sequel and the definitive edition of blinding forest.

Things Ori did better than Hollow knight-
1. Movement: the movement in this game is very smooth and enjoyable, and the game uses it to great extent.

2. graphics: although hollow knight has great stylized graphics, this game overall looks great,

3. Platforming: the game has great movement and it also uses the great movement in boss fights, most of the boss fights in this game are heavily platforming focused. a lot like the game Celeste. 

4. Puzzles: Hollow knight lacked a lot of puzzles, which this game has a lot. There are a few puzzles that just get annoying after a while but at least they have puzzles. 
----------
Things Hollow knight did better than Ori and the blinding forest,
-combat: overall in terms of combat the game was lacking and hollow knight easily takes combat

-world building: I think the world is great and has wasted potential. the world is easily 2x the size of hollow knight but some areas simply seem dead and nothing seems to be going on in the areas.

-enemy variation: the enemy variation is very lacking, most of the time different regions just have re-skinned versions of previous enemy you encounter.

Game Length- now its no question that this game is shorter than hollow knight, and I don't think there was any way they could make the game as long as hollow knight, but I beat the game in about 13 hours with 70% completion. I was missing a great sum of hp and the blue things. I also missed 2 abilitys somehow? which my friend pointed out. A dash would have been helpful. 

------
should you buy this game? 
- yea, it satisfied me for the most part, the game lacks combat but is overall a way more chill and laid back experience compared to hollow knight, 
-I would also buy the bundle, although I have not played the second game, I think it is a overall upgrade compared to blinding forest, although I have not played will of the wisps yet.

Ori and the Blind Forest is an absolute masterpiece of a game, and it's easy to see why it's become a favorite for so many gamers. From its breathtaking visuals to its emotionally resonant storytelling, every aspect of this game is crafted with care and attention to detail.

First and foremost, let's talk about the visuals. The hand-painted art style is absolutely stunning, with vibrant colors and lush environments that draw you into the world of Nibel. Every frame of this game feels like a work of art, and it's clear that a lot of love went into creating each and every pixel.

But Ori and the Blind Forest isn't just a pretty face â€“ it also has a compelling story to tell. The narrative follows Ori, a small guardian spirit, as they embark on a quest to save their home from an encroaching darkness. Along the way, they'll encounter a cast of memorable characters, each with their own motivations and struggles. The story is told primarily through visual storytelling and environmental cues, which adds an extra layer of depth to the experience.

Of course, no discussion of Ori and the Blind Forest would be complete without mentioning its gameplay. At its core, this is a platformer with Metroidvania elements, and it excels in both departments. The controls are tight and responsive, allowing for precise movement and platforming challenges that are both challenging and rewarding. The addition of abilities that can be unlocked and upgraded as you progress adds a layer of depth to the gameplay, giving you new ways to traverse the environment and overcome obstacles.

But perhaps the most impressive thing about Ori and the Blind Forest is its emotional impact. This is a game that knows how to tug at your heartstrings, with moments of joy, sorrow, and everything in between. The relationship between Ori and their adoptive mother, Naru, is particularly touching, and there were more than a few moments that brought a tear to my eye.

In conclusion, Ori and the Blind Forest is a truly special game that deserves all the praise it has received and more. Its stunning visuals, compelling story, and tight gameplay come together to create an experience that is as unforgettable as it is beautiful. If you haven't had the chance to experience it for yourself, I highly recommend giving it a try â€“ you won't be disappointed.

I'm just gonna start this review by saying I am extremely bias because despite the 15 hours of playtime on steam that isn't even scratching the surface of how many hours I've poured into this game. I own both Ori titles on Steam, Xbox and Switch and have all the achievements for the first game on the last two platforms which just leaves the Steam version and I'll get to that one of these days. The point is Ori and the Blind Forest is a solid Metroidvania that has pretty much everything I want from the genre, a beautifully realized world with adorable and lovable characters and wonderful traversal mechanics as you explore and unravel the mysteries of the forest. Overall Ori as a character and as an IP means a lot to me and about the only negative thing I can say about this game is that the combat can be a bit repetitive though there are more options than people often realize. If you like Metroidvanias with quick and nimble movement and are into the more fantasy and magic oriented setting I would definitely recommend giving Ori a shot though as I established at the beginning I would probably recommend it to everyone anyway. Ori is usually pretty affordable too so even if there isn't a sale you won't be breaking the bank

An absolute classic in metroidvania platformers. Though the difficulty gets a bit challenging towards the end, it was fun the whole way through and ends at the perfect time. The level design never feels repetitive and always challenge the player in unique ways that never overstay their welcome. The puzzles were just challenging enough for you to feel like you were using your brain, but not much more. Both the visual and auditory aspects shine brightly and make the game an absolute wonder to experience. The story is a bit basic, but I feel a more complex story would have just bogged it down. Even with 100% completion, I never felt like it was a slog and never felt I was wasting my time grinding. My only complaint is that there's 0 replayability. this game would severely benefit from a ng+. other than that, a beautiful (and beautifully frustrating) game that will be remembered as a classic for generations to come.

If you're like me and thought about expanding the Ori experience by grabbing the original on a discount after you completed Ori WotW - don't. WotW is a masterpiece that does everything that this original does, and infinitely better at that.

There's a number of incredibly glaring game design flaws in this original, but the biggest one of them all is the lack of auto-saves. In a game that is all about surviving hazardous environments. To save your game you need to get and use Energy to create a manual save point on the map. Obtained this one item but made a wrong step or got hit by a stray mob projectile? Have fun doing everything **again** from where you last saved and acquiring it again - or going out of your way to find an energy cell somewhere so that you can create another save point further ahead. And believe me, you need a save a **lot** - everything either hurts like a truck or one-shots. You can easily get stuck in one segment for hours upon hours because you have a save point with 1hp in the middle of another endless corridor of one-shot hazards. 

tl;dr Ori WotW is a fantastic game. Don't sully your experience by playing the original.
